entries.content: Objections are requests for more information or clarity, not rejections.
Acknowledge and validate the prospect's objection before responding.
"Many of my clients felt the same way initially."
entries.notes: Part of the feel-felt-found framework, showing social proof.
Part of the feel-felt-found framework, presenting the solution or benefit.

entries.content: Use the feel-felt-found framework to structure responses to common objections.
Ask clarifying questions to understand the real reason behind an objection.
"When you say [the objection], what specifically do you mean by that?"
entries.notes: Question to uncover the root of an objection.

entries.content: Isolate the objection to confirm it is the only barrier.
"Besides [this objection], is there anything else preventing us from moving forward?"
entries.notes: Question to isolate the main objection.

entries.content: Reframe price objections by focusing on value, ROI, and the cost of inaction.
Turn an objection into a question you can answer or a point you can address.
Pre-empt potential objections by addressing them proactively in the presentation.
Use testimonials or case studies as social proof to overcome credibility objections.
Summarize the discussion and confirm understanding after addressing an objection.
"Does that make sense?" or "Have I addressed your concern about that?"
entries.notes: Questions to confirm the objection has been handled.

entries.content: Handle 'I need to think about it' by exploring what specifically needs consideration.
"What information do you feel you're missing to make a decision today?"
entries.notes: Question to uncover the root of 'need to think' objection.
